Yale President Schmidt to Speak at Commemoration
by Kim Lankford
Benno C. Schmidt, Jr., President of Yale University, will be
the featured speaker in Shriver
Hall Sunday at 4 p.m. at the
Commemoration Day ceremony,
the celebration of the 111th year
since the founding of the Johns
Hopkins University.
In addition to Schmidt, former
Italian prime minister Giovanni
Spadolini and five distinguished
faculty members will be
presented with honorary degrees
from the University.
A graduate of Yale University,
Schmidt previously served as
dean of the Columbia University

School of Law. According to
Mary Ellen Robinson, assistant
director for special events,
"Schmidt was chosen by the
President's office and the Board
of Trustees."
Senior Assistant to the President, Jill McGovern added that
Schmidt was chosen because of
his commitment to "freedom of
expression distinguished to legal
research, and his position as the
leader of a preeminent institution."
Schmidt has been commended
for his analyses of many issues of
freedom of expression including

Scholarships and Internships
The National College Internship Service, specializing
in internship development for
college students, is now accepting applications for Summer
1987 internships.
Placements are available
with sponsoring companies in
New York City, on Long
Island, and in Westchester.
Placements are individually
designed, fully supervised,
and evaluated. New for 1987:
more paid internships.
Please call or write for application material: National
College Internship Service,
374 New York Avenue, Huntington, New York 11743, or
phone (516)673-044.0, or contact your career and internship
placement offices on campus.

INTELSAT has a limited
number of summer internships
for students of high academic

standing and proven research
skills whose interests lie in
space communications and
related policy issues. Appropriate majors include:
engineering, physics, political
econ. The internship is located
in Washington, D.C. The stipend is $350 per month for a
10 week period. Application
deadline is April 15.
Students who have completed their junior year by
May, 1987 can apply for internship positions with the
New York State Assembly.
Applications require an official transcript, two letters of
recommendation, and other
supporting documents. The internship runs from June 15 to
August 21 and pays $2500.
The deadline for application is
April 1. For more information
contact J.D. Goodyear, Office
of Academic Advising.

Jewish Party to be Held
At Hyatt Tomorrow
by Vensive Lamb
In an effort to "increase Jewish
identity" on the Homewood campus, the Hopkins Jewish Appeal
will co-sponsor a semi-formal this
Saturday at the Hyatt Regency
Baltimore.
"The purpose of this event is
to let people know that the HJA
is on campus," said Evan
Muney, chairman of the Hopkins
Jewish Appeal, "and to have a
good time."
Along with the Hopkins Jewish
Appeal, Jewish Appeal organization members from Goucher College and Towson State University will co-host the event, which
is titled the "United Jewish Appeal Campus Campaign."
High attendence is expected
from students at George
Washington
University,
American University, the University
of Maryland, and

Georgetown University, as well
as other area colleges and
universities.
The HJA, which provides
funds for numerous Baltimore
charities including various day
care centers, old age homes, and
Jewish community centers, also
provides funds for the United
Jewish Appeal, which sends its
monies to Israel.
"One of the purposes of the
HJA is to try to get Jewish
students to identify as Jews," said
Muney, "and at the same time,
get them to see their responsibility to fellow Jews around the
world that are in need.
Tickets for the 9 p.m. until 1
a.m. semi-formal are $5 in advance and $6 at the door.
Refreshments will be served.
Anyone interested in the HJA or
who wants more information on
the semi-formal should contact
Evan Muney at 235-5521.

While headlines across the
world proclaim the release of

agencies and governments.
Jewish Students Association

will head the Hopkins contingent
of twenty students in their trek to
the nation's capital. "In the past
we've been able to [create]
awareness in the issue," said
Degen.
After spending a night in one
of two Washington synagogues,
the Coalition's lobbyists will partake in a series of seminars by the
Coalition's sponsors to insure that
all the participants are accurately informed on the topic.
This year's sponsors, who not
only donate their time and effort,
but supplies and other resources,
Senators Frank
includes

"Thank those who have helped
and encourage them to visit the

Liberty, which broadcasts news

hold protests across the country

8/FEBRUARY 20, 1987

The Hopkins NewsoLetter Council President
Assuages Fears
A Cool $11,000
Spring is on its way, but you don't need
a calendar or a walk outside to prove it. At
Hopkins, there's a much more reliable way
to mark the passage of winter. Just wait for
the late-February announcement of next
year's tuition increase. It comes like
clockwork.
In a Student Council meeting (which has
now become an annual ritual more temporally precise than the Gilman chimes),
University President Steven Muller, flocked by an entourage of deans, a vicepresident, and administrative heavyweights, announced an $800 tuition hike for
next year. The increase will bring
undergraduate tuition at Hopkins up to a
cool $11,000 for the next academic year.
Of course, the increase comes as no surprise to anyone who has been at Hopkins
for any length of time. Last year, tuition
shot up $800 as it did the year before that.
In fact, tuition has increased at a rate of six
percent or more, per year, for the last thirteen years, and according to University officials, there's no reason to hope that that
trend will change very much in the immediate future.
So, all things considered, the size and
timing of the hike seemed to be quite
predictable.
What was equally predictable was the
Administration's defense of the increase.
As usual, Muller came to the Council
meeting armed with a list of the tuition
charged at 106 other colleges and universities. He was happy to point out that
Hopkins was about fiftieth on the list, all
costs considered.
Muller's list is always interesting and hits
a soft spot in most students. (Almost
everyone at Hopkins revels in comparisons
of universities a la Barron's Guide.)
But such lists hardly provide a justification for tuition increases. We believe
there's no reason to compare Hopkins with
other schools when tuition decisions are
made. Hopkins ought to assess its own
financial needs and resources, make its
decision, and justify it regardless of the

prices charged elsewhere. After all, comparing tuition rates among universities
with the purpose of justifying one's own
tuition is a little like justifying tax increases
by quoting the tax rates paid in other countries. It doesn't mean very much.
In fact, there probably are good reasons
for increasing tuition. But those reasons
barely surfaced at the Council meeting.
Despite the similarities in Muller's
presentation of the tuition increase this year
to those of years past, there was one striking difference. Wednesday's meeting was
the first meeting in three years at which
Muller broke the news of the size of the
increase to Council. We commend him for
doing so.
Last year, we asked Muller about a possible tuition increase, and he released the size
of the hike to us weeks before he appeared
at Council. And in 1985, Muller tipped off
Jon Lana, then Student Council president,
in advance.
This year, Muller apparently decided to
return to the tradition of breaking the news
at a Council meeting itself.
Of course, we appreciate getting scoops
like the tuition increase last year and won't
complain if it happens again. But, the Student Council is the elected representative
organization of the undergraduates at
Hopkins, and should therefore be the first
to be formally informed of decisions like
an $800 tuition increase. Clearly, notifying Council is the most diplomatic way to
release the news of an increase.
As the initial din caused by the announcement of the tuition increase subsides, the
hike will likely be soon forgotten. Nevertheless, the Administration owes the
students who will foot the bill a more complete account of the reasons for the increase. Specifically, a report detailing the
rising expenses of operating the University should be presented to Council.
Only then will students be able to make
some reasonable conclusions about the
necessity of a tuition increase.

Snaring a Speaker
The issue of commencement speakers is
always a touchy one. No matter how
famous or infamous a given speaker may
be, there are sure to be those among the
Senior Class who will complain. This year,
however, we suspect that the complainers
will be fewer and farther between than in
recent years, thanks in large measure to the
work of the Graduation Speaker
Committee.
After nearly four months of hard work,
the committee managed to snare sportswriter and announcer Howard Cosell for
the afternoon convocation ceremony. All
the members of the Senior Class should be
pleased.
In recent years, the "prestige" of the
Senior Class speakers has vacillated
dramatically. In '84, William F. Buckley,
Jr. graced the ceremony; in '85, actor John
Houseman took the podium; and in '86,
oceanographer Roger Revelle gave the
senior address. While all three speakers
performed well, Senior Class morale seemed to be particularly high at the speech of
the most famous of the three.

This year, the ceremony seems destined
for the same success as Graduation '84.
Commencement will feature a "brandname" Senior Class speaker with wide appeal; and a morning speaker, Vartan
Gregorian, the president of the New York
Public Library, who will likely provide an
interesting speech as well.
Considering the fiscal restraints imposed on the Graduation Speaker Committee,
attracting a speaker of Cosell's fame must
have been no easy endeavor. In an age
when a well-known speaker can clear a
five-digit salary for a one-hour lecture, the
$2,500 honorarium offered by the senior
class could hardly serve as bait for most
speakers. Without considerable generosity on the part of the speaker and diplomacy
on the part of the Graduation Speaker Committee, it would be impossible to imagine
attracting a lecturer of Cosell's stature.
This year, we look forward to an interesting commencement ceremony and
commend the Graduation Speaker Committee for tackling a difficult job and
prevailing.

The desire to take an afternoon
nap is a sign of maturity, as
children, with their lack of
foresight, fight until exhaustion to
avoid the pleasure, and adults, if
they think for a moment, realize
that while anybody can do lunch,
only the mighty may then sleep.
For the past several years, I have
pursued the perfect nap, and am
closer to momentary bliss than
when I first started.
Sleeping in class is worse than
not sleeping. Not only is it rude,
but it rarely gets past a few jerks
of the head without leading to
snoring, drooling, falling out of
the chair, or some other atrocity.
For their foolishness, people
sleeping in class deserve to be
whacked on the head, or at least
noticed and made fun of. The real
power nap must take place in a
comfortable environment. More
importantly, it must take place in
private.
The length of the nap would
seem to be the most important
variable, but if it is to be a nap
at all it should not exceed half an
hour, or forty-five minutes at
most. Anything longer is probably the result of exhaustion and
when I wake from a three or four
hour slumber, the entire day or
night is ruined, as well as my
sleep schedule for the rest of the
week. After all, the purpose of a
nap is to relax and then perhaps
return to work, not to collapse
and struggle back to a sleepinduced stupor.
Setting the alarm clock is easy
enough. Setting the thermostat is
not at all easy. If the room is
warm I will feel more tired and
take longer to fall asleep than if
the room is cool. After falling
asleep I will probably have a
nightmare, wake up, feel
miserable and still tired, and fall
asleep again for another
nightmare, usually about
neglected work. Only if the room
is just cool enough are naps
refreshing.
Of course, waking is the biggest problem. Waking poorly can
make the entire experience a
waste of time. If the timing is off,
waking can leave a person too
hyped-up to go back to whatever

they were doing. This seems to
happen when the nap is too short:
it is just enough to give a person
a jolt of random energy, and this
will throw them off and give them
insomnia later. If the nap is too
long, or the waking process is
drawn out, the nap will turn out
to be completely useless, a draining of energy, leaving the napper
more tired than when he started.
The perfect nap comes down to
a few minor details and perfect
awakening. This should come just
before the alarm clock is about to
start up, to give the illusion of
freedom ("I can sleep as long as
I want"), and it should take only
a second to snap to a fully functional state. When carried off in
this form, the nap will sometimes
include a special bonus, an idea
for a story, the solution to a puzzle, or the sudden desire to do
something. The best naps are
inspiring.
And then there are dreams.
Superstition has it that I cannot
dream my own death, but I have:

with dust wooden floor, in a
mystical valley filled with people
on horseback in Asian armor, a
man with a mustache pointed a fat
chrome musket at my face; I

by Peter Thornton
According to the Kinsey Report
on Human Sexuality, one out of
every ten people is gay and one
in four is bisexual or has strong
bisexual tendencies. For the
undergraduate population at
Hopkins, those figures work out
to 200 gays and possibly 500
bisexuals.
GALA—the Gay and Lesbian
Alliance—is the response of conscientious and concerned people
to this situation. The group's purpose, according to president
Joshua Stuart is twofold. First,
they provide support for gays
who are coming out—not actually making public, but rather ceasing to hide their sexuality. This
transition may be extremely difficult emotionally and many gays
are unable to make it on their
own. "Their self-esteem has been
so beaten down that they can't get
up the courage to meet other people who can help them," says
Stuart. He emphasizes "the need
to reach out and let people know
that other gay people exist." The
process of coming out is further

complicated by social pressures;
"It's not uncommon for parents
to beat their (gay) children,
specifically for fathers to beat
their gay daughters." And what
about the job environment? "People get fired every day (for being
gay)," says Stuart. "It's sad, but
it happens. All the time."
GALA's other main function is
the education of the straight community about gays and the gay
community. "I think that educa-

tion is the key to understanding
and acceptance," says Stuart, and
he stresses the fact that the issue
must be humanized for the educational approach to be successful.
"The biggest problem is that it is
difficult to humanize an un-

familiar issue in a coherent, rational way." He gives an example: "All kinds of people who
have real problems with gays are
changed completely when they
realize that their brother or their
best friend, or maybe a parent, is
gay. Then the problem is
humanized, then they can see
how stupid their bias is." Of
course not everyone will have this
sort of contact, so the problem
remains.
The Alliance has been well
supported by the administration in
both of these purposes. "The administration has been great, to the
extent that the administration as
far as we deal with it is Mary
Ellen Porter and Andrea Perry,"
says Stuart. This year, a
representative for the Alliance
met with all of the Housemasters
in order to educate them on the
special problems of gay
freshmen. "Statistically, there
are between 60 and 70 gays in the
freshman dorms, and the
Housemasters need to know how
to help them, and where to send
them for help they're not
qualified to give." In that func-

tion, the support service for gays,
"the White House has been very
good in regards to their sensitivity
to the gay community," says
Stuart.
The Alliance has meetings,
open to the public, on the first
Tuesday of every month at 5:00
p.m. in the basement of Levering.
The meetings serve primarily a
business function. Additionally,
there is a "rap group" which
meets in Conference Room A "to

give gay students a chance to
meet other people as well as a
chance to talk about gay
concerns."
When asked about the main
topics of discussion, and
specifically whether AIDS is

discussed at the rap sessions,
Stuart responds, "On a few occasions, yes. Primarily the
discussion is about our own personal fears [concerning the
disease]. It's important that we
learn to go on living, that we not
stop our lives out of fear." He
adds, "It is a mistake to think of
AIDS as a gay disease merely
because it started in the gay commUnity. AIDS is not selective.
For the time being it is primarily
a concern of the gay community
because that's where it's most
prominent. That's changing
quickly, though, as the disease
spreads. You can pick up a
Newsweek and you'll find an ad
for condoms, and it will talk
about how AIDS is not a gay
disease."
Asked if there was anything
else the public should be more
aware of, Stuart responds, "Yes.
The difference between the word
gay and the term homosexual.
Homosexual is a very clinical
word, and as a label, it is applied
to us by others. We call ourselves
gay, not homosexual."

Debate Continues
Parlous Precedent
by Howard Zachary Robbins
A popular vision of Hell is that
of constant discord and argument.
To a Hopkins debater, Heaven
could not be better described.
1987 marks the sixth year of
the Johns Hopkins Parliamentary
Debate Council, but debate at
Hopkins enjoys a far lengthier
history than that. Woodrow
Wilson, when he was a graduate
student at Hopkins, felt the need
for a forum to debate current
issues on campus. From that
organization, The House of Commons [featured elsewhere on
these pages], was spawned a
debate team that competed on an
inter-collegiate level. Until 1982
it was on-topic debate, with
researched topics, that Hopkins
debaters pursued at Homewood.
Interest in this factual debate
flagged, though, so the
parliamentary form of debate
popular in Canada and Great Britain was introduced to Hopkins
students still determined to spend
their time arguing.
If debate brings to mind stern
arguments over nuclear war and
abortion, then "parliamentary
debate" would seem a foreign
term. A resolution, usually a line
from a poem, book, song, or even
graffiti, is read to the team randomly assigned to present the
case ten minutes before the case
must be presented. What this
whole process boils down to is
that in ten brief minutes, the duo
must come up with some
debatable proposal for another
two-member team to oppose. The
result, both teams hope, is a genuinely amusing yet convincing
argument to sway the judge(s)
toward their point of view.

A debater's ultimate goal is
"hardware"—trophies, silver
plates and wooden gavels to cart
back from tournaments and hang
on walls. To acquire these dandy
items, debaters must prove to
judges in five rounds of debate
over two days that they have won
the arguments, and have been
more eloquent in the process.
Though the quantification of
one's speaking ability is a difficult
endeavor, judges must do so on
the scoring ballots. Speakers are
rated on a scale of one to thirty,
but most scores range in the low
20's.
The hope of hardware and the
thrill of inter-collegiate competition has increased the ranks of the

active members today. The dreams
of trophies have certainly not
gone unrealized. The Fall of '86
brought fifteen trophies to
Homewood from tournaments at
UMBC, Penn and Columbia.
Hopkins debaters also competed
at Brown, Vassar and Harvard.
1987 is off to an optimistic start,
a Hopkins team having won fifth
place at the Goucher debate tournament, the first of the semester.
All trophies, however, are not
created equal. The greatest honor
for any parliamentary debater is
to win at the World Debate Tournament, held in a different coun-

try every year. Since the 1984
season, Hopkins has sent its
argumentative representatives as
far away as Dublin, Ireland to
battle Canadian, American,
English, Irish, Scottish and
Australian teams. Last year the
Hopkins delegation won third
place at World, better than any
other American team had done
previously.
The Debate Council's hopes
for the future are stellar.
Membership is on a constant rise
and, assuming a sufficient rise in
funding, these debaters can continue the Hopkins tradition of
humor and victory up and down
the East Coast and around the
globe.
The newly-elected President
of the Council, junior Chris
Arzt, is seeking to expand the
success of the team and funding
to match. A sale of fruit baskets
raised much-needed dollars for
the Council, and other projects
are in the works. Arzt is joined
by sophomore Aneil Shirke as
Vice President of Operations,
sophomore Charles Fitzgerald as
Vice President of Development,
freshman Howard Robbins as
Treasurer, and junior Eric Kane
as Secretary.
Looking forward toward
Spring, the Debate Council plans
to send teams to tournaments at
Randolph-Macon, Princeton,
NYU, Yale and Wesleyan, with
other tournaments still in question. Hopkins debate forges ahead
with the hope of solving problems
from behind a podium, not a gun.
Humor, wit and eloquence reign
supreme, and Hopkins is always
reaching for the front of the pack.

What we mean when we talk about a

We think of them as being a group in

questioning comes up is because in any kind

of questions asked and those kinds of

so high. Which is to say, to write a novel

Ike, Macmillan To View Graduation,
Speak To University Assembly In June

HAROLD MACMILLAN

British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and Dwight D,
Eisenhower, President of the United States, will attend the commencement exercises at Hopkins on Tuesday, June 10.
White House Press Secretary James Haggerty also announced that
Macmillan will deliver the principal address at the ceremonies. Macmillan is scheduled to receive an honorary degree from the University.
Macmillan will be in the United States to confer with the President
and other U.S. leaders.
The Prime Minister is expected to arrive in the United States on
June 7 and will first speak at graduation exercises at DePaul University, in Greencastle, Indiana, his mother's home state, on June 8.
The original invitation to Mr. Macmillan to address the graduating
Hopkins students was extended personally by Dr. Milton Eisenhower,
president of Hopkins and the brother of the President. His acceptance
was received at the White House a week ago.
The Prime Minister, the son of an English father and an American
mother, accepted his post January 10, 1957, at a time when a rift
was appearing between England and the U.S. over the former's policy
toward Egypt.
He is generally considered to have been a major force in helping
to repair Anglo-American relations.
Macmillan, a personal friend of the President since 1942, met
Eisenhower as the British Cabinet's political representative at
Eisenhower's wartime headquarters in Africa.
When Eden became Prime Minister in 1955, he named Macmillan
to succeed him as Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. Eight months
later Macmillan took over England's finances by becoming Chancellor
of the Exchequer.
Macmillan will be making his fifth visit to the U.S. in the past three
years. His most recent appearance in Washington last October led
to a joint statement with President Eisenhower of a "declaration of
common purpose" between the United states and Britain.

One Woman's Bunky Solution
by Loren Fox
Black Widow. Directed by
Bob Rafelson. Produced by
Harold Schneider. Twentieth
Century Fox Films. Rated R.
It's a shame that amid the
hoopla over Platoon many people
will overlook the new Bob
Rafelson film, Black Widow.
Rafelson's first feature, Five Easy
Pieces, gave the world the most
memorable chicken-salad scene
and linked him with that group of
young directors who were reenergizing American cinema in
the early seventies, including
George Lucas and Robert
Altman. Unlike Lucas and
Altman, Rafelson has managed to
continued producing quality
films. Black Widow has been
compared to Jagged Edge, that
courtroom mess which had all the
suspense of a Road Runner cartoon. Black Widow is, rather, the
most effective thriller to come
around since Blood Simple, and
like that film, it draws from the
film noir genre for its atmosphere. This gives an arty,
small budget feel to it, although
it is a decidedly big money, big
cast production.
The plot is juicy: a woman
whose identity no one is sure of
(Theresa Russell) is marrying
wealthy men, murdering them,
and inheriting their money. First,
as a Chicago socialite, she
poisons her publishing magnate
husband. She leaves New York
for Dallas, where she poses as a
Charleston belle and marries a
toy tycoon. She slips from New

York chic to Southern hospitality as easily as she slips the
odorless poison into her husband's brandy.
Enter Alex Barnes (Debra
Winger), a data analyst for the
Justice Department. Alex notices
a connection between these
wealthy men who all pass away
shortly after marrying. This intrigues her, and she spends her
free time trying to track down the
murderess. She has a lot of free
time, as she oddly avoids dating
men. Alex and "the widow" are
a study in opposites: one scruffy,
neurotic, building a life void of
men;
the
other
cool,
sophisticated, building her life
around men.
Ronald Bass's screenplay picks
up as we are let in to see Russell
prepare for her next victim. She
chooses Edwin McCory (Nicol
Williamson), millionaire coin
collector. Russell studies ancient
coins and appears at McCory's •
museum as a charming New
Englander. She makes a huge
donation, gets on the board of
directors, and begins to flirt with
McCory. Her technique is
fascinating, as Russell uses makeup, hair dye, and acting to assume
whole new identities and change
ages.
And she doesn't pick easy
prey, dumb pansies who live in
the world of the gullible. McCory
notes her interest in coins and
says, "I bet you looked those up
just to impress me." Edwin
checks her credentials and finds
that, yes, she is the dream girl
from Mount Holyoke College he
was meant to marry.

Murder Wealthy Husbands,
Entrance Pursuing Cop
Meanwhil, Winger realizes
who the killer is and goes to prove
it to herself. She lets Russell
know that she is snooping around
and that she is staying at the
Hilton, and Russell goes there.
There she is told that Winger
transferred to another hotel, but
stalwart Debra is just hiding
across the street from the second
hotel, waiting to see if Russell
will follow that far. Russell does,
and Winger has the proof to continue the chase. In a fantastic moment, Russell realizes she's been
duped and has a conniption fit in
her car.
Paranoid, Russell makes quick
work of McCory and leaves for
Hawaii. Against the advice of her
boss (Dennis Hopper), Barnes
quits her dull job and pursues. In
Hawaii the film opens up, and the
scenery opens up as well, turning
from boardrooms and bedrooms
to volcanoes and rivers. Lush
greens and deep blues provide an
alluring backdrop as the pace
quickens. Russell has set her
sights on Paul (Sami Frey), a
hotel developer. Under an assumed name, Barnes joins a scuba
class and befriends Russell. From
there on, it is a stylish match of
wits.
This is an odd, teasing movie.
The scenery teases as it
charms—Rafelson's
selfconscious direction teases with its
images—and the actresses tease
their men and each other. As
Winger becomes more like
Russell, their relationship gains•
an uneasy sexual tension. Winger
and Russell flirt with each other.
At one point in which Winger is
giving Russell mouth-to-mouth,-

she says, "I hope you don't take
this personally." The film is
chock full of good lines like that,
as when Russell boldly announces
to a sleazy private-eye, "Let me
tell you two things about myself.
I'm rich . . . and I'm wealthy."
Sami Frey is sexy enough as
Paul, but Williamson and Hopper
are wasted in their roles as colorless, "nice" guys. One can't
help but imagine that Hitchcock
would have turned the men into
eccentrics, but Rafelson gives the
movie totally to Russell and
Winger. Debra Winger plays the
same scruffy, bookish role she
took in Legal Eagles, only she
trades the humor for obsession.
Between that movie and this one,
she seems to be constructing
some sort of unattractive "image" which undermines the sexy
charisma that made her stand out
in An Officer and a Gentleman.
While she won't win any
Oscars as long as there are
pitiable farm girls the Academy
can idealize, Theresa Russell
turns in one of the best performances of 1987. There is some
internal rage, pity and love which
fuels this dynamo of evil. Russell
is, at the same time, stunningly
elegant and seductive. Rafelson
has toned down her "admissions" to Winger, and keeps the
audience guessing at her true
motives. In a move that most noir
would shun, he keeps the audience guessing even after the
movie's over. It works, and the
film emerges as a well-made
character study, tense and full of
twists. If you like a juicy thriller,
you'll fall for the Black Widow.

Dr. Stephen Breckler, assistant professor of psychology, relaxes during
by Joseph M. Gergyes
Steven J. Breckler, assistant
professor of psychology, must
spend a few years secluded at the
Rotunda while his real home in
Ames is being renovated, but that
doesn't mean that he'll take the
opportunity to catch up on some
well deserved rest. He will instead spend the time out "in the
field", gathering data, then piecing it together and pulling it apart
at his computer, and finally coming up with an answer or explanation to his research problem. As
a social psychologist, his research
problems are people problems, a
search for why people have the
attitudes they do, how they were
formed and what can be done
about them. The information
garnered from his research may
be used by organizations to
understand the way people act
and react, by leaders and
managers to know better how to
mobilize people, and by society
in general to understand the inner
workings of human beings.
Dr. Breckler received his
undergraduate degree from the
University of California, San
Diego and went on to complete
his graduate studies at Ohio State.
After performing his postdoctoral
work at Northwestern University, Dr. Breckler came to Hopkins
in 1984 as an assistant professor.
Still fresh from student life, Dr.
Breckler stands out amongst his
colleagues as one of the younger
members of the faculty. Although
new to the field of academia,
Breckler seems to have made the
transition well, teaching and
spending his time researching
a variety of topics in his field.
The National Science Foundation chose to recognize Breckler's
researching skills recently by
naming him as a winner of one of
its prestigious Presidential Young
Investigator Awards. Breckler

Hoopmen Prevail
by Danny Kofos
The men's varsity basketball
team had another "down and up"
week, dropping two and winning
one.
On Saturday, the Blue Jays faced Widener College (20-3, 8-0)
the third ranked team in Division
III. Widener opened a ten point
lead over the Jays early in the first
half, and maintained control the
rest of the game. High scorers for
Hopkins
included
Mike
Latimore, who dropped in
twelve, and Jedan Phillips with
nine points. Scott Stevens led the
Waves with 18 points.
Monday night saw four Jays hit
for double figures, but that still
wasn't enough to overcome Ursinus (11-12). Rodney Joyner and
John Maddox dropped in 12 each
for the Bears, while Phillips and
Chris Wasson sunk 14 each for
the Jays. Latimore and the ever
improving Joel Sieperski added
eleven points each. The Jays were
close at the half, down 33-26, but
could never make a run and ended up losing 69-58.
Wednesday was Hopkins day
as the Jays found themselves on
the other side of things. Senior
Chris Wasson, who has been the
most consistent performer for the
Jays all year, led all scorers with
19 points, pacing Hopkins to a
70-45 rout over Haverford.
Hopkins was in control of this

one all the way, leading at the half
32-18. Phillips added 18 for the
Jays, while Sieperski, Latimore,
and Paul Heiss evenly divided the
rest of the scoring.
The varsity basketball team
wraps up its season this week,
traveling to Washington College
this Saturday and then closing the
year with a make-up game against
Western Maryland on Tuesday at
the Athletic Center at 8:00 P.M.
On another note of interest,
Chris Wasson has been named to
the GTE District II All-Academic
team, according to an announcement by the College Sports Information Directors of America
(COSIDA).
Wasson is majoring in International Studies and is also serving
as a Teaching Assistant in the
Writing Seminars Department.
He is carrying a cumulative grade
point average of 3.33. He has
been on the Dean's List for two
years, and is treasurer of the
Alpha Delta Phi fraternity.
Wasson is the son of Mr. and
Mrs. Samuel Wasson and resides
in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He graduated
from Radnor High School in St.
David's, Pa.
The current basketball season
has been his best one. He is
leading Hopkins in scoring with
297 points in 21 games and is
shooting .490 from the field. He
also leads the team in assists.

While headlines across the

agencies and governments.
Jewish Students Association

will head the Hopkins contingent

the nation's capital. "In the past
we've been able to [create]
awareness in the issue," said
Degen.
After spending a night in one
of two Washington synagogues,
the Coalition's lobbyists will partake in a series of seminars by the
Coalition's sponsors to insure that
all the participants are accurately informed on the topic.
This year's sponsors, who not

"Thank those who have helped
and encourage them to visit the

The Hopkins NewsoLetter Council President
Assuages Fears
A Cool $11,000
Spring is on its way, but you don't need
a calendar or a walk outside to prove it. At
Hopkins, there's a much more reliable way
to mark the passage of winter. Just wait for
the late-February announcement of next
year's tuition increase. It comes like
clockwork.
In a Student Council meeting (which has
now become an annual ritual more temporally precise than the Gilman chimes),
University President Steven Muller, flocked by an entourage of deans, a vicepresident, and administrative heavyweights, announced an $800 tuition hike for
next year. The increase will bring
undergraduate tuition at Hopkins up to a
cool $11,000 for the next academic year.
Of course, the increase comes as no surprise to anyone who has been at Hopkins
for any length of time. Last year, tuition
shot up $800 as it did the year before that.
In fact, tuition has increased at a rate of six
percent or more, per year, for the last thirteen years, and according to University officials, there's no reason to hope that that
trend will change very much in the immediate future.
So, all things considered, the size and
timing of the hike seemed to be quite
predictable.
What was equally predictable was the
Administration's defense of the increase.
As usual, Muller came to the Council
meeting armed with a list of the tuition
charged at 106 other colleges and universities. He was happy to point out that
Hopkins was about fiftieth on the list, all
costs considered.
Muller's list is always interesting and hits
a soft spot in most students. (Almost
everyone at Hopkins revels in comparisons
of universities a la Barron's Guide.)
But such lists hardly provide a justification for tuition increases. We believe
there's no reason to compare Hopkins with
other schools when tuition decisions are
made. Hopkins ought to assess its own
financial needs and resources, make its
decision, and justify it regardless of the

prices charged elsewhere. After all, comparing tuition rates among universities
with the purpose of justifying one's own
tuition is a little like justifying tax increases
by quoting the tax rates paid in other countries. It doesn't mean very much.
In fact, there probably are good reasons
for increasing tuition. But those reasons
barely surfaced at the Council meeting.
Despite the similarities in Muller's
presentation of the tuition increase this year
to those of years past, there was one striking difference. Wednesday's meeting was
the first meeting in three years at which
Muller broke the news of the size of the
increase to Council. We commend him for
doing so.
Last year, we asked Muller about a possible tuition increase, and he released the size
of the hike to us weeks before he appeared
at Council. And in 1985, Muller tipped off
Jon Lana, then Student Council president,
in advance.
This year, Muller apparently decided to
return to the tradition of breaking the news
at a Council meeting itself.
Of course, we appreciate getting scoops
like the tuition increase last year and won't
complain if it happens again. But, the Student Council is the elected representative
organization of the undergraduates at
Hopkins, and should therefore be the first
to be formally informed of decisions like
an $800 tuition increase. Clearly, notifying Council is the most diplomatic way to
release the news of an increase.
As the initial din caused by the announcement of the tuition increase subsides, the
hike will likely be soon forgotten. Nevertheless, the Administration owes the
students who will foot the bill a more complete account of the reasons for the increase. Specifically, a report detailing the
rising expenses of operating the University should be presented to Council.
Only then will students be able to make
some reasonable conclusions about the
necessity of a tuition increase.

Snaring a Speaker
The issue of commencement speakers is
always a touchy one. No matter how
famous or infamous a given speaker may
be, there are sure to be those among the
Senior Class who will complain. This year,
however, we suspect that the complainers
will be fewer and farther between than in
recent years, thanks in large measure to the
work of the Graduation Speaker
Committee.
After nearly four months of hard work,
the committee managed to snare sportswriter and announcer Howard Cosell for
the afternoon convocation ceremony. All
the members of the Senior Class should be
pleased.
In recent years, the "prestige" of the
Senior Class speakers has vacillated
dramatically. In '84, William F. Buckley,
Jr. graced the ceremony; in '85, actor John
Houseman took the podium; and in '86,
oceanographer Roger Revelle gave the
senior address. While all three speakers
performed well, Senior Class morale seemed to be particularly high at the speech of
the most famous of the three.

This year, the ceremony seems destined
for the same success as Graduation '84.
Commencement will feature a "brandname" Senior Class speaker with wide appeal; and a morning speaker, Vartan
Gregorian, the president of the New York
Public Library, who will likely provide an
interesting speech as well.
Considering the fiscal restraints imposed on the Graduation Speaker Committee,
attracting a speaker of Cosell's fame must
have been no easy endeavor. In an age
when a well-known speaker can clear a
five-digit salary for a one-hour lecture, the
$2,500 honorarium offered by the senior
class could hardly serve as bait for most
speakers. Without considerable generosity on the part of the speaker and diplomacy
on the part of the Graduation Speaker Committee, it would be impossible to imagine
attracting a lecturer of Cosell's stature.
This year, we look forward to an interesting commencement ceremony and
commend the Graduation Speaker Committee for tackling a difficult job and
prevailing.

The desire to take an afternoon
nap is a sign of maturity, as
children, with their lack of
foresight, fight until exhaustion to
avoid the pleasure, and adults, if
they think for a moment, realize
that while anybody can do lunch,
only the mighty may then sleep.
For the past several years, I have
pursued the perfect nap, and am
closer to momentary bliss than
when I first started.
Sleeping in class is worse than
not sleeping. Not only is it rude,
but it rarely gets past a few jerks
of the head without leading to
snoring, drooling, falling out of
the chair, or some other atrocity.
For their foolishness, people
sleeping in class deserve to be
whacked on the head, or at least
noticed and made fun of. The real
power nap must take place in a
comfortable environment. More
importantly, it must take place in
private.
The length of the nap would
seem to be the most important
variable, but if it is to be a nap
at all it should not exceed half an
hour, or forty-five minutes at
most. Anything longer is probably the result of exhaustion and
when I wake from a three or four
hour slumber, the entire day or
night is ruined, as well as my
sleep schedule for the rest of the
week. After all, the purpose of a
nap is to relax and then perhaps
return to work, not to collapse
and struggle back to a sleepinduced stupor.
Setting the alarm clock is easy
enough. Setting the thermostat is
not at all easy. If the room is
warm I will feel more tired and
take longer to fall asleep than if
the room is cool. After falling
asleep I will probably have a
nightmare, wake up, feel
miserable and still tired, and fall
asleep again for another
nightmare, usually about
neglected work. Only if the room
is just cool enough are naps
refreshing.
Of course, waking is the biggest problem. Waking poorly can
make the entire experience a
waste of time. If the timing is off,
waking can leave a person too
hyped-up to go back to whatever

they were doing. This seems to
happen when the nap is too short:
it is just enough to give a person
a jolt of random energy, and this
will throw them off and give them
insomnia later. If the nap is too
long, or the waking process is
drawn out, the nap will turn out
to be completely useless, a draining of energy, leaving the napper
more tired than when he started.
The perfect nap comes down to
a few minor details and perfect
awakening. This should come just
before the alarm clock is about to
start up, to give the illusion of
freedom ("I can sleep as long as
I want"), and it should take only
a second to snap to a fully functional state. When carried off in
this form, the nap will sometimes
include a special bonus, an idea
for a story, the solution to a puzzle, or the sudden desire to do
something. The best naps are
inspiring.
And then there are dreams.
Superstition has it that I cannot

with dust wooden floor, in a
mystical valley filled with people
on horseback in Asian armor, a
man with a mustache pointed a fat
chrome musket at my face; I

by Peter Thornton
According to the Kinsey Report
on Human Sexuality, one out of
every ten people is gay and one
in four is bisexual or has strong
bisexual tendencies. For the
undergraduate population at
Hopkins, those figures work out
to 200 gays and possibly 500
bisexuals.
GALA—the Gay and Lesbian
Alliance—is the response of conscientious and concerned people
to this situation. The group's purpose, according to president
Joshua Stuart is twofold. First,
they provide support for gays
who are coming out—not actually making public, but rather ceasing to hide their sexuality. This
transition may be extremely difficult emotionally and many gays
are unable to make it on their
own. "Their self-esteem has been
so beaten down that they can't get
up the courage to meet other people who can help them," says
Stuart. He emphasizes "the need
to reach out and let people know
that other gay people exist." The
process of coming out is further

complicated by social pressures;
"It's not uncommon for parents
to beat their (gay) children,
specifically for fathers to beat
their gay daughters." And what
about the job environment? "People get fired every day (for being
gay)," says Stuart. "It's sad, but
it happens. All the time."
GALA's other main function is
the education of the straight community about gays and the gay
community. "I think that educa-

tion is the key to understanding
and acceptance," says Stuart, and
he stresses the fact that the issue
must be humanized for the educational approach to be successful.
"The biggest problem is that it is
difficult to humanize an un-

familiar issue in a coherent, rational way." He gives an example: "All kinds of people who
have real problems with gays are
changed completely when they
realize that their brother or their
best friend, or maybe a parent, is
gay. Then the problem is
humanized, then they can see
how stupid their bias is." Of
course not everyone will have this
sort of contact, so the problem
remains.
The Alliance has been well
supported by the administration in
both of these purposes. "The administration has been great, to the
extent that the administration as
far as we deal with it is Mary
Ellen Porter and Andrea Perry,"
says Stuart. This year, a
representative for the Alliance
met with all of the Housemasters
in order to educate them on the
special problems of gay
freshmen. "Statistically, there
are between 60 and 70 gays in the
freshman dorms, and the
Housemasters need to know how
to help them, and where to send
them for help they're not
qualified to give." In that func-

tion, the support service for gays,
"the White House has been very
good in regards to their sensitivity
to the gay community," says
Stuart.
The Alliance has meetings,
open to the public, on the first
Tuesday of every month at 5:00
p.m. in the basement of Levering.
The meetings serve primarily a
business function. Additionally,
there is a "rap group" which
meets in Conference Room A "to

give gay students a chance to
meet other people as well as a
chance to talk about gay
concerns."
When asked about the main
topics of discussion, and
specifically whether AIDS is

discussed at the rap sessions,
Stuart responds, "On a few occasions, yes. Primarily the
discussion is about our own personal fears [concerning the
disease]. It's important that we
learn to go on living, that we not
stop our lives out of fear." He
adds, "It is a mistake to think of
AIDS as a gay disease merely
because it started in the gay commUnity. AIDS is not selective.
For the time being it is primarily
a concern of the gay community
because that's where it's most
prominent. That's changing
quickly, though, as the disease
spreads. You can pick up a
Newsweek and you'll find an ad
for condoms, and it will talk
about how AIDS is not a gay
disease."
Asked if there was anything
else the public should be more
aware of, Stuart responds, "Yes.
The difference between the word
gay and the term homosexual.
Homosexual is a very clinical
word, and as a label, it is applied
to us by others. We call ourselves
gay, not homosexual."

Debate Continues
Parlous Precedent
by Howard Zachary Robbins
A popular vision of Hell is that
of constant discord and argument.
To a Hopkins debater, Heaven
could not be better described.
1987 marks the sixth year of
the Johns Hopkins Parliamentary
Debate Council, but debate at
Hopkins enjoys a far lengthier
history than that. Woodrow
Wilson, when he was a graduate
student at Hopkins, felt the need
for a forum to debate current
issues on campus. From that
organization, The House of Commons [featured elsewhere on
these pages], was spawned a
debate team that competed on an
inter-collegiate level. Until 1982
it was on-topic debate, with
researched topics, that Hopkins
debaters pursued at Homewood.
Interest in this factual debate
flagged, though, so the
parliamentary form of debate
popular in Canada and Great Britain was introduced to Hopkins
students still determined to spend
their time arguing.
If debate brings to mind stern
arguments over nuclear war and
abortion, then "parliamentary
debate" would seem a foreign
term. A resolution, usually a line
from a poem, book, song, or even
graffiti, is read to the team randomly assigned to present the
case ten minutes before the case
must be presented. What this
whole process boils down to is
that in ten brief minutes, the duo
must come up with some
debatable proposal for another
two-member team to oppose. The
result, both teams hope, is a genuinely amusing yet convincing
argument to sway the judge(s)
toward their point of view.

A debater's ultimate goal is
"hardware"—trophies, silver
plates and wooden gavels to cart
back from tournaments and hang
on walls. To acquire these dandy
items, debaters must prove to
judges in five rounds of debate
over two days that they have won
the arguments, and have been
more eloquent in the process.
Though the quantification of
one's speaking ability is a difficult
endeavor, judges must do so on
the scoring ballots. Speakers are
rated on a scale of one to thirty,
but most scores range in the low
20's.
The hope of hardware and the
thrill of inter-collegiate competition has increased the ranks of the

active members today. The dreams
of trophies have certainly not
gone unrealized. The Fall of '86
brought fifteen trophies to
Homewood from tournaments at
UMBC, Penn and Columbia.
Hopkins debaters also competed
at Brown, Vassar and Harvard.
1987 is off to an optimistic start,
a Hopkins team having won fifth
place at the Goucher debate tournament, the first of the semester.
All trophies, however, are not
created equal. The greatest honor
for any parliamentary debater is
to win at the World Debate Tournament, held in a different coun-

try every year. Since the 1984
season, Hopkins has sent its
argumentative representatives as
far away as Dublin, Ireland to
battle Canadian, American,
English, Irish, Scottish and
Australian teams. Last year the
Hopkins delegation won third
place at World, better than any
other American team had done
previously.
The Debate Council's hopes
for the future are stellar.
Membership is on a constant rise
and, assuming a sufficient rise in
funding, these debaters can continue the Hopkins tradition of
humor and victory up and down
the East Coast and around the
globe.
The newly-elected President
of the Council, junior Chris
Arzt, is seeking to expand the
success of the team and funding
to match. A sale of fruit baskets
raised much-needed dollars for
the Council, and other projects
are in the works. Arzt is joined
by sophomore Aneil Shirke as
Vice President of Operations,
sophomore Charles Fitzgerald as
Vice President of Development,
freshman Howard Robbins as
Treasurer, and junior Eric Kane
as Secretary.
Looking forward toward
Spring, the Debate Council plans
to send teams to tournaments at
Randolph-Macon, Princeton,
NYU, Yale and Wesleyan, with
other tournaments still in question. Hopkins debate forges ahead
with the hope of solving problems
from behind a podium, not a gun.
Humor, wit and eloquence reign
supreme, and Hopkins is always
reaching for the front of the pack.

Commons holds weekly meetings
on Wednesday night. The president of the club chairs the
meetings and the prime minster
provides the resolution to be
discussed. Any member of the
club, called cabinet members,
may write a resolution, but it is
up to the prime minister to present it. Last Wednesday, the
News-Letter sat in on their
meeting and observed the
proceedings.
The members trickled in —six
fellows and one lady in all. The
administrative details were
discussed and dispensed with.
Then the arbitrator hammered his
gavel and the fun began. What
followed was a lively discussion
on the utility of limits on jury
awards. The members quickly
factioned into very opinionated
groups. There was mad notetaking, frequent outbursts and
crashes of the gavel. The debate
was filled with amusing anecdotes
(a person shaving his head with
a lawnmower) and barely veiled
statements masquerading as questions. All the arguments
culminated in a vote which was
something of an anti-climax to the
heated debate. Then, the

members decided on who would
write resolutions for the next
week, and everyone filed out.
One cabinet member assured
me that one need not know
Parliamentary procedure to participate. Apparently, it can be
picked up fairly easily. Neither is
an eloquent speaking ability or an
up-to-the-minute knowledge of
current events required. One
could go in having completely no
idea of the meaning of the resolution and come out an enlightened
being. One of the members who

HAROLD MACMILLAN

British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and Dwight D,
Eisenhower, President of the United States, will attend the commencement exercises at Hopkins on Tuesday, June 10.
White House Press Secretary James Haggerty also announced that
Macmillan will deliver the principal address at the ceremonies. Macmillan is scheduled to receive an honorary degree from the University.
Macmillan will be in the United States to confer with the President
and other U.S. leaders.
The Prime Minister is expected to arrive in the United States on
June 7 and will first speak at graduation exercises at DePaul University, in Greencastle, Indiana, his mother's home state, on June 8.
The original invitation to Mr. Macmillan to address the graduating
Hopkins students was extended personally by Dr. Milton Eisenhower,
president of Hopkins and the brother of the President. His acceptance
was received at the White House a week ago.
The Prime Minister, the son of an English father and an American
mother, accepted his post January 10, 1957, at a time when a rift
was appearing between England and the U.S. over the former's policy
toward Egypt.
He is generally considered to have been a major force in helping
to repair Anglo-American relations.
Macmillan, a personal friend of the President since 1942, met
Eisenhower as the British Cabinet's political representative at
Eisenhower's wartime headquarters in Africa.
When Eden became Prime Minister in 1955, he named Macmillan
to succeed him as Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. Eight months
later Macmillan took over England's finances by becoming Chancellor
of the Exchequer.
Macmillan will be making his fifth visit to the U.S. in the past three
years. His most recent appearance in Washington last October led
to a joint statement with President Eisenhower of a "declaration of
common purpose" between the United states and Britain.

One Woman's Bunky Solution
by Loren Fox
Black Widow. Directed by
Bob Rafelson. Produced by
Harold Schneider. Twentieth
Century Fox Films. Rated R.
It's a shame that amid the
hoopla over Platoon many people
will overlook the new Bob
Rafelson film, Black Widow.
Rafelson's first feature, Five Easy
Pieces, gave the world the most
memorable chicken-salad scene
and linked him with that group of
young directors who were reenergizing American cinema in
the early seventies, including
George Lucas and Robert
Altman. Unlike Lucas and
Altman, Rafelson has managed to
continued producing quality
films. Black Widow has been
compared to Jagged Edge, that
courtroom mess which had all the
suspense of a Road Runner cartoon. Black Widow is, rather, the
most effective thriller to come
around since Blood Simple, and
like that film, it draws from the
film noir genre for its atmosphere. This gives an arty,
small budget feel to it, although
it is a decidedly big money, big
cast production.
The plot is juicy: a woman
whose identity no one is sure of
(Theresa Russell) is marrying
wealthy men, murdering them,
and inheriting their money. First,
as a Chicago socialite, she
poisons her publishing magnate
husband. She leaves New York
for Dallas, where she poses as a
Charleston belle and marries a
toy tycoon. She slips from New

York chic to Southern hospitality as easily as she slips the
odorless poison into her husband's brandy.
Enter Alex Barnes (Debra
Winger), a data analyst for the
Justice Department. Alex notices
a connection between these
wealthy men who all pass away
shortly after marrying. This intrigues her, and she spends her
free time trying to track down the
murderess. She has a lot of free
time, as she oddly avoids dating
men. Alex and "the widow" are
a study in opposites: one scruffy,
neurotic, building a life void of
men;
the
other
cool,
sophisticated, building her life
around men.
Ronald Bass's screenplay picks
up as we are let in to see Russell
prepare for her next victim. She
chooses Edwin McCory (Nicol
Williamson), millionaire coin
collector. Russell studies ancient
coins and appears at McCory's •
museum as a charming New
Englander. She makes a huge
donation, gets on the board of
directors, and begins to flirt with
McCory. Her technique is
fascinating, as Russell uses makeup, hair dye, and acting to assume
whole new identities and change
ages.
And she doesn't pick easy
prey, dumb pansies who live in
the world of the gullible. McCory
notes her interest in coins and
says, "I bet you looked those up
just to impress me." Edwin
checks her credentials and finds
that, yes, she is the dream girl
from Mount Holyoke College he
was meant to marry.

Murder Wealthy Husbands,
Entrance Pursuing Cop
Meanwhil, Winger realizes
who the killer is and goes to prove
it to herself. She lets Russell
know that she is snooping around
and that she is staying at the
Hilton, and Russell goes there.
There she is told that Winger
transferred to another hotel, but
stalwart Debra is just hiding
across the street from the second
hotel, waiting to see if Russell
will follow that far. Russell does,
and Winger has the proof to continue the chase. In a fantastic moment, Russell realizes she's been
duped and has a conniption fit in
her car.
Paranoid, Russell makes quick
work of McCory and leaves for
Hawaii. Against the advice of her
boss (Dennis Hopper), Barnes
quits her dull job and pursues. In
Hawaii the film opens up, and the
scenery opens up as well, turning
from boardrooms and bedrooms
to volcanoes and rivers. Lush
greens and deep blues provide an
alluring backdrop as the pace
quickens. Russell has set her
sights on Paul (Sami Frey), a
hotel developer. Under an assumed name, Barnes joins a scuba
class and befriends Russell. From
there on, it is a stylish match of
wits.
This is an odd, teasing movie.
The scenery teases as it
charms—Rafelson's
selfconscious direction teases with its
images—and the actresses tease
their men and each other. As
Winger becomes more like
Russell, their relationship gains•
an uneasy sexual tension. Winger
and Russell flirt with each other.
At one point in which Winger is
giving Russell mouth-to-mouth,-

she says, "I hope you don't take
this personally." The film is
chock full of good lines like that,
as when Russell boldly announces
to a sleazy private-eye, "Let me
tell you two things about myself.
I'm rich . . . and I'm wealthy."
Sami Frey is sexy enough as
Paul, but Williamson and Hopper
are wasted in their roles as colorless, "nice" guys. One can't
help but imagine that Hitchcock
would have turned the men into
eccentrics, but Rafelson gives the
movie totally to Russell and
Winger. Debra Winger plays the
same scruffy, bookish role she
took in Legal Eagles, only she
trades the humor for obsession.
Between that movie and this one,
she seems to be constructing
some sort of unattractive "image" which undermines the sexy
charisma that made her stand out
in An Officer and a Gentleman.
While she won't win any
Oscars as long as there are
pitiable farm girls the Academy
can idealize, Theresa Russell
turns in one of the best performances of 1987. There is some
internal rage, pity and love which
fuels this dynamo of evil. Russell
is, at the same time, stunningly
elegant and seductive. Rafelson
has toned down her "admissions" to Winger, and keeps the
audience guessing at her true
motives. In a move that most noir
would shun, he keeps the audience guessing even after the
movie's over. It works, and the
film emerges as a well-made
character study, tense and full of
twists. If you like a juicy thriller,
you'll fall for the Black Widow.

Steven J. Breckler, assistant

at his computer, and finally coming up with an answer or explanation to his research problem. As
a social psychologist, his research
problems are people problems, a
search for why people have the
attitudes they do, how they were
formed and what can be done
about them. The information
garnered from his research may
be used by organizations to
understand the way people act
and react, by leaders and
managers to know better how to

University of California, San
Diego and went on to complete
his graduate studies at Ohio State.
After performing his postdoctoral
work at Northwestern University, Dr. Breckler came to Hopkins
in 1984 as an assistant professor.
Still fresh from student life, Dr.
Breckler stands out amongst his
colleagues as one of the younger
members of the faculty. Although
new to the field of academia,
Breckler seems to have made the
transition well, teaching and
spending his time researching
a variety of topics in his field.

recipient.

Fords Crash As
Hoopmen Prevail
by Danny Kofos
The men's varsity basketball
team had another "down and up"
week, dropping two and winning
one.
On Saturday, the Blue Jays faced Widener College (20-3, 8-0)
the third ranked team in Division
III. Widener opened a ten point
lead over the Jays early in the first
half, and maintained control the
rest of the game. High scorers for
Hopkins
included
Mike
Latimore, who dropped in
twelve, and Jedan Phillips with
nine points. Scott Stevens led the
Waves with 18 points.
Monday night saw four Jays hit
for double figures, but that still
wasn't enough to overcome Ursinus (11-12). Rodney Joyner and
John Maddox dropped in 12 each
for the Bears, while Phillips and
Chris Wasson sunk 14 each for
the Jays. Latimore and the ever
improving Joel Sieperski added
eleven points each. The Jays were
close at the half, down 33-26, but
could never make a run and ended up losing 69-58.
Wednesday was Hopkins day
as the Jays found themselves on
the other side of things. Senior
Chris Wasson, who has been the
most consistent performer for the
Jays all year, led all scorers with
19 points, pacing Hopkins to a
70-45 rout over Haverford.
Hopkins was in control of this

one all the way, leading at the half
32-18. Phillips added 18 for the
Jays, while Sieperski, Latimore,
and Paul Heiss evenly divided the
rest of the scoring.
The varsity basketball team
wraps up its season this week,
traveling to Washington College
this Saturday and then closing the
year with a make-up game against
Western Maryland on Tuesday at
the Athletic Center at 8:00 P.M.
On another note of interest,
Chris Wasson has been named to
the GTE District II All-Academic
team, according to an announcement by the College Sports Information Directors of America
(COSIDA).
Wasson is majoring in International Studies and is also serving
as a Teaching Assistant in the
Writing Seminars Department.
He is carrying a cumulative grade
point average of 3.33. He has
been on the Dean's List for two
years, and is treasurer of the
Alpha Delta Phi fraternity.
Wasson is the son of Mr. and
Mrs. Samuel Wasson and resides
in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He graduated
from Radnor High School in St.
David's, Pa.
The current basketball season
has been his best one. He is
leading Hopkins in scoring with
297 points in 21 games and is
shooting .490 from the field. He
also leads the team in assists.

with big noses and glasses (I'd wear a Groucho disguise, but. . .it
